description.narrative: The project aims to increase climate change resilience at landscape level by applying the principles of ecosystem based adaptation.

title.narrative: Mid-term evaluation: Ecosystem based adaptation project

description.narrative: The project objective is to maintain the water provisioning services supplied by mountain and steppe ecosystems by internalizing climate change risks within land and water resource management regimes.
drainage basin

1. Number of eco-regional EBA strategy programs and action plans adopted by National and Aimag Governments 2. Decrease in average Rural Poverty rate within the target watershed population. 3. Number of Soums replicating EBA principles and practices within the target eco-regions

comment.narrative: 1. No single Aimag governments have eco-regional EBA strategy programs and action plans adopted by National and Aimag Governments 2. Rural Poverty rate are 0.433 in Ulz basin and 0.495 in Kharkhiraa/Turgen basin. 3. No Soums apply EBA principles and practices within the target eco-regions.

title.narrative: Disaster risk reduction at the local level

description.narrative: Strengthening local level capacities for disaster risk reduction, management and coordination in Mongolia.
The goal of the project is to facilitate a decentralized disaster management through sustainable prevention, response, and coordination mechanisms.
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

Indicator 1. Level of progress towards establishing policy and regulatory frameworks to enable clear roles and responsibilities to support Disaster reduction management at the local level. It is measured by the scales from 0-3: Scale#0. Roles and responsibilities unclear; Law on disaster needs changes Scale#1. Policy recommendations formulated and management mechanisms identified Scale#2. Action plan, recommendations and management mechanisms are validated through relevant stakeholders Scale#3. Law on Disaster reflects required changes to support the disaster risk management at th local level and implementation rolled out
Indicator 2. Extent of efforts made in strengthening the competencies and procedures tailored for local level disaster management mechanisms Scale#0. Low human, technical and financial capacities at the local level for effective preparedness and response to disasters. No formal body for disaster management at the soum and community level Scale#1. Capacity needs determined and validated. Awareness raised on hazards, vulnerabilities and responses measures (a detailed set of indicators for this scale is found in the project RRF such as sampling survey and # of media programmes and training materials disseminated; # of vulnerability and multi-hazard maps for city, district, aimag and soum level). Scale#2. Resource mobilization and material acquisition plan (focus on aimag and soum level emergency units) supported and trainings rolled out (detailed set of indicators for this scale is in the RRF such as # of methodologies and software for maintenance and exchange of disaster related information; % of increase in material acquisition of aimag and district EMDs, self-help groups and task forces); Scale#3. Operational DRR professional teams and task forces successfully respond to emergencies making use of a volunteer support and priority actions stated in the national disaster policy and programme. (see RRF for detailed list)
Indicator 3. Level of pr

description.narrative: It aims to assist the Parliament of Mongolia in improving legislating drafting processes through supporting ex-ante policy analysis and stakeholder open dialogue; in increased access of citizens to their elected representatives.

Technical assistance for the development of a National Training programme for local elected representatives, a comprehensive package for capacity building through induction training and the tools to support hurals in their oversight functions.
independent political entity
Elections - elections

Indicator 1. Existence of a comprehensive review of the state building, conducted through consultative processes and formulation of the recommendations for institutional reforms. Scale: Yes/No.
Indicator 2. Extent of the consultative policy support for state structuring and legislative drafting
It is measured by the scales from 0-3: Scale#0. No standard process for legal drafting Scale#1. Procedural standards available for legal drafting, which is formulated based on the policy studies . Scale#2. Law on Legislative drafting is approved after stakeholder dialogues Scale#3. Legal implementation and drafting procedures are monitored and the proposals for institutional reform/state structuring are developed
Indicator 3.Scope/extent of the improved relationship between parliament and citizens
It is measured by the scales from 0-3: Scale#0.Little awareness and use of the Right to Information Law and restricted access for citizens to parliament. Scale#1. Recommendations formulated for citizen's access to parliament based on the study and public relations strategy developed for parliament outreach Scale#2. A public relations strategy is developed as part of improving parliamentary outreach; Scale#3. Recommended action for improving citizen's accessapproved and the implementation rolled out

title.narrative: Capacity Strengthening of Local Self-Governing Bodies

description.narrative: It aims to strengthen capacities of local hurals to fulfil their representational and oversight mandates for improved accountability of local governments and local service delivery.

participating-org.narrative: SWISS AGENCY FOR DEVELOPMENT AND COOPERATION - SDC

description.narrative: The project aims to assist in strengthening local self-governing bodies through rolling out nationwide training, improved downward accountability of elected representatives and increased oversight capacity of local hurals.

participating-org.narrative: SWISS AGENCY FOR DEVELOPMENT AND COOPERATION - SDC

description.narrative: independent political entity
Accountability - local government finance

provider-org.narrative: SWISS AGENCY FOR DEVELOPMENT AND COOPERATION - SDC
SWISS AGENCY FOR DEVELOPMENT AND COOPERATION - SDC

comment.narrative:
Output 1: 1.1. Thematic training to be organized for hural members based on needs assessment. 1.2. Women's leadership training to be completed to cover all 21 aimags and 9 districts. 1.3. Study tour on local self governance to be organized to learn from countries with advance local self governance.
Output 2: 2.1. Perception study on local self-governing bodies to be conducted. 2.2. Grants to hurals to be continued on areas where capacity building is most needed.
Output 3: Output 4: 4.1.Draft proposals for amendment to LATUG and related laws to be developed and submitted to Sub standing committee of the Parliament on local governance. 4.2. khural.mn website to be further operationalized as knowledge and experience sharing platform.

description.narrative: Stregthening the governement capacity of National Development Policy and Planning
The project aims at providing support to the Government of Mongolia to improve its economic policy formulation, strategic planning and monitoring both at national and local level.
independent political entity

Extent of progres made in drafting Development policy and planning law and its implementation.
It is measured by the scales from 0-3: 0. Law does not exist 1. Draft law exists with national consultations 2. Draft law exists and is being discussed in the Parliament 3. Law adopted and its implementation rolled out

comment.narrative:
Scale 0: Law does not exist and is not implemented
Narrative explanation of the baseline: There is no legal basis for integrated and coordinated planning system in the country. Weak capacity in planning both at national and local level.

description.narrative: Network of Managed Resource Protected Area

"Mongolia's Network of Managed Resource Protected Areas" is to catalyze the strategic expansion of Mongolia's Protected area system through establishment of a network of community conservation area covering under-represented terrestrial ecosystems.
Energy - policy, planning and administration
End of Project target/indicator: 1. 19.2 Mln. ha 2. 80Mln. ha

comment.narrative: 1. Total Local Protected Area (without community managed areas) is 16 Mln.ha, but not included in the NPA System. 2. Total area of under-represented ecosystems is 102 Mln.ha.

description.narrative: Catalyze the strategic expansion of Mongolia’s PA system through establishment of a network of community conservation areas covering under-represented terrestrial ecosystems.
Hectares within the total protected area system, including community conservation areas

comment.narrative: Total LPA (without community managed areas) is 16 Mln. ha, but not included in the NPA System.
19.2 Mln. ha

Total LPA (without community managed areas) was found to be 20.5 million ha based on the recent in-depth survey on the LPA coverage. Although it appears that the end of project target has already been reached, this new figure is largely as a result of more accurate investigation on the LPA coverage which tends to be fluid (as local authority can gazette and de-gazette or the set period for protection can expire) . 20.5 million ha includes 3 new LPAs and extension of Gulzat LPA, which were facilitate directly by the project, accounting for 0.25 million ha in total. However LPA are not yet recognized as part of the national PA system. With the approval of the revised SPA Law in the current version, the LPAs will be officially part of the PA system.

description.narrative: Hectares of seven under-represented ecosystems within total protected areas system, including community conservation areas

comment.narrative: Total area of under-represented ecosystems is 102 Mln. ha.
80 Mln.ha

Hectares of seven under-represented ecosystems within total protected areas system, including community conservation areas, is 102 million ha. This is according to a more accurate assessment of the LPA coverage supported by the project as above.

description.narrative: Establishment of new PA category for strategic PA expansion
Specific NPA legislation amended and/or new regulation adopted to establish and guide effective management of community conservation areas

comment.narrative: 0 No national law and/or regulation adopted as described
1 national law and/or regulation adopted as described

1.Regulation on "Taking land under local protection" (2000) is currently under revision towards setting up clear criteria and processes for LPAs, including CCAs.
2.As a result of 1st National Forum for CBOs organized by MEGDT jointly with all donor organizations, it’s been issued an Order #07 of Parliament Standing Committee on Agriculture and Environment dated July 09, 2015 towards undertaking required actions and allocation of state budget to strengthen the governance and management of CCAs and build capacity of CBOs throughout the country.
3.Working group for drafting revised laws of Special Protected Area and Buffer Zone was re- established due to recently re-structured Ministry of Environment, Green Development &Tourism (MEGDT). The working group has refined the revised drafts through series of meetings.
The following key issues reflected to the revised draft SPA Law in relation to CCA:
-Local protected areas are part of the national protected areas’ network
-In addition to government, it’s proposed collaborative and community management governance types for both state and local protected areas.
4.A comprehensive feasibility study on current legal framework for community conservation areas and proposal of revisions/amendments to key legislations, including Law on Special Protected Areas, Environmental Protection Law and Law on Land .The study result has given practical basis to legitimize the community conservation areas to become an effective part of Mongolia's National protected areas system and allowing for community-based conservation management

description.narrative: Number of community conservation areas legally recognized as part of the NPA system according to the amended national legislation and/or regulation

comment.narrative: 0 community conservation areas legally recognized as part of the NPA system
50 community conservation areas legally recognized as part of the NPA system

30 community groups, of which 15 newly established, with total area of 340000 ha officially recognized and contracted with the soum governor for taking management responsibility over land and biodiversity in target 3 LPAs. By March 2015, a total of 1629 community conservation areas (8.2 mln. hectare) are recorded throughout the country with user rights over forest, wildlife, water and pasture resources.

description.narrative: Emplacement of institutional capacity and resource base development to ensure sustainability of Managed Resource PAs
METT Scores for at least three LPAs converted and/or established as community conservation areas

comment.narrative:
Need METT scores for three pilot sites:
Gulzat LPA 36
Khavtgar 26
Tumenkhaan-Shalz LPA 22

Each baseline METT score increased to:
Gulzat LPA 50
Khavtgar 40
Tumenkhaan-Shalz LPA 26
METT will be reapplied at project mid-term.

description.narrative: PAAD has a fully functional, staffed and government funded community conservation area resource center providing on-going monitoring, support and extension training for local conservation decision-makers

comment.narrative: 0 functional institutional center within PAAD to support effective community conservation areas
1 functional institutional center within PAAD to support effective community conservation areas
1 resource person within PAAD is under recruitment to oversee CCAs at national level

description.narrative: Decentralised regional PA governance framework involving community and local governments (Soum and Aimag) established in 3 demonstration sites

comment.narrative:
0 project sites applying legally enforceable management plan to improve conservation of wide-ranging species and mitigate conservation threats
0 effective conservation management at regional level

3 project sites applying legally enforceable management plan to improve conservation of wide-ranging species and mitigate conservation threats
3 effective conservation management model developed in project target sites: Khavtgar, Gulzat, Tumenkhaan-Shalz LPA (as center of excellence)

3 project sites applying legally enforceable management plan to improve conservation of wide-ranging species and mitigate conservation threats
3 effective conservation management model developed in project target sites: Khavtgar, Gulzat, Tumenkhaan-Shalz LPA s. In Gulzat an NGO is mandated by the local government for the management of the Gulzat LPA. In Tumenkhaan-Shalz LPA, a joint Management council (consisting representatives of stakeholders from all three soums) is established for the management of this LPA. In Khavtgar, the local government decided the LPA will have a status of a “state–owned company”, while a full time manager will be recruited.
The following common strategic documents were approved by the local government and operational in three project areas: Mid-term Strategic Plan (2015-2025); Management Plan (2015-2019) and Hunting Management Plan (2015-2016).
Specifically for ‘Tumenkhaan-Shalz’ LPA:
-Livestock sustainable development programme along with Livestock offset regulation has been developed for all 3 soums and approved by local government.
-The following standardized forms and templates for efficient management of CCAs are developed and utilized: Model bylaws for community management organizations, Model Terms of references of key officers, Model management and business plans for LPAs, model resolutions of local government.

description.narrative: Policing and enforcement of laws and regulations for biodiversity conservation results in reduction of threats and no net loss of key indicators at three pilot sites

description.narrative: Investing in sustainable/green buildings in Mongolia, therefore, offers a compelling opportunity for mitigating GHG emissions while also improving the quality of life for the citizens.
Approved a medium sized project (MSP): “Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Actions in the Construction Sector in Mongolia”.

comment.narrative: Lack of capacity and institutional arrangements in the identification and prioritization of appropriate and cost-effective energy efficient measure.
To develop a full-fledged proposal of a medium sized project (MSP): “Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Actions in the Construction Sector in Mongolia”.

description.narrative: It provides a rapid and flexible response mechanism to support upstream policy results and innovation.

title.narrative: Project Document and Note to File

description.narrative:
It aims to provide fast support for upstream policy innovation and scaling up activities.
(This is 2015 budget set up for $15.5K from 04400; $80.8 from 11999 and $200K from 11888 funds as per EF 2015 Work Plan.)

The existing mechanisms for conducting upstream policy and innovation activities were reviewed, and new approaches to achieve the above objectives were explored including defining a new project type and streamlining existing delivery mechanisms. The result of this analysis concluded that the recommended approach is to combine the DAS and DSS delivery mechanisms into one rapid response facility for upstream policy and innovation results (renamed the “Engagement Facility”) and to revisit the procedures and guidelines around the use of this facility to encourage a greater potential for policy impact.

comment.narrative: The Government of Mongolia and the United Nations Development Programme have developed the UNDP Country Programme Action Plan (CPAP) for 2012-2016 on the basis of long standing cooperation between the Government and UNDP in effectively supporting Mongolia's development.
to support upstream policy iinovations and scaling up as well as corporate initiatives such as SDGs

title.narrative: Land Degradation Offset and Mitigation in Western Mongol

description.narrative: This project will assist the Government of Mongolia to reduce negative impacts of mining on rangelands in the western mountain and steppe region.
Land Degradation Offset and Mitigation in Western Mongolia.
Energy - policy, planning and administration

Area of pastoral production system and natural habitats in western Mongolia under integrated planning and management as shown by incorporation of eco-regional assessment into land use plans: End of project target: 41.5 million ha
Area set aside from mining related development, for ecological sensitivity including pasture values (through local and national PA designations) derived from Eco-regional assessment) End of project target: 10% increase
Level of institutional capacity for implementation of mitigation and offsetting framework as indicated by Capacity scorecard End of project target: Improved capacity indicated by an increase of at least 25% over baseline (ie. a score of 51.25 = 53.4%)

comment.narrative: Area of pastoral production system and natural habitats in western Mongolia under integrated planning and management as shown by incorporation of eco-regional assessment into land use plans: 0 Area set aside from mining related development, for ecological sensitivity including pasture values (through local and national PA designations) derived from Eco-regional assessment): 11.35M ha national PAs and 2.08 M ha Local PAs Total = 13.43 M ha Level of institutional capacity for implementation of mitigation and offsetting framework as indicated by Capacity scorecard: 41 out of a possible 96 = 42.7%

1. Project implementation Unit is operational: office space obtained and equipped, project team recruited. 2. Pilot landscapes' final selection conducted and confirmed. 3. MOU between related mining companies, MEGDT and UNDP signed.
